NewsDetail.Title: New Learning Model Web Site
NewsDetail.Abstract: The site uses the Learning Model to teach the Learning Model. Visitors are invited to “Prepare” by reviewing the content of the site.
NewsDetail.Author: Brian Schmidt
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
A moving chalkboard, video clips, and interactive activities, create a “virtual classroom” where people can learn more about the BYU-Idaho Learning Model. This new web site on the Learning Model was developed to help students take greater responsibility for their own learning. It integrates both the principles and the process steps of the Learning Model in a format that allows a quick overview or detailed investigation.

 

Student guides welcome visitors to the site and direct them through the process steps of “Prepare,” “Teach One Another,” and “Ponder/Prove.” Along the way, visitors can learn more about the five Learning Model principles by viewing reflections from students and faculty, or by reading supportive scriptures, quotes and examples.

 

The site uses the Learning Model to teach the Learning Model. Visitors are invited to “Prepare” by reviewing the content of the site. An online forum allows members of the university community to “Teach one Another” by discussing questions and sharing ideas. Additionally visitors can “Ponder” their progress through a self-assessment and “Prove” their understanding by taking an online test.

 

One can see the Learning Model at work by visiting two different classrooms on campus. Video clips highlight classroom interactions, reveal the instructor’s teaching strategies, and show how students prepare, teach one another, and ponder/prove their understanding. Additional resources on the site cover misconceptions, link to related talks, and provide instructor resources.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

President Clark is asking all students to visit the new Learning Model site in preparation for a special forum that he will be conducting on Thursday, January 29th. Using a discussion format similar to the Disciple/Leader Forum, President Clark will lead a discussion on how students can deepen their learning by investing more effort in using the principles of the Learning Model. While the forum is targeted to students, faculty members are also invited to this event that will be held from 2-3 pm in the Hart Auditorium.

 

A recent survey found that 41% of the student body could identify four out of the five the principles of the Learning Model. This level of understanding has been reached through faculty members teaching the model to their students. To supplement this effort, institutional messaging, such as the forum and web site, are being developed. A student advisory council has been organized to foster better understanding and practice of Learning Model principles.
